author: ryanleeschneider
content: The EIP-2930 spec doesn't explicitly say that the tx hash of an access list tx is `keccak256(rlp([1, chainId, nonce, gasPrice, gasLimit, to, value, data, access_list]))` but I assume that's the case since that's what the signature values are over?

author: lightclient
content: <@!388751025789468672> no it's actually `keccak(1 || rlp([chainId, nonce, gasPrice, gasLimit, to, value, data, access_list])`

author: lightclient
content: although it isn't really explicit, it is implicit since the inner value above is the "consensus" serialization of the tx and a tx hash should be the keccak of the consensus serialization

author: ryanleeschneider
content: Thanks ya that makes sense, it might make the EIP a little more readable/easier to implement if that part was spelled out but not sure if we want to make changes to the EIP at this stage.

author: 0xraino
content: Hmm, i need to double check that in the besu code then. We might have the hash calced differently right now

author: ryanleeschneider
content: My reading of the besu code was that it's the same since besu takes the hash of the output of `encodeForTransactionTrie` but entirely possible I'm reading it wrong.

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe it is specified explicitly in 2718.

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, no, sorry.  There is another EIP for typed transactions over gossip.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@388751025789468672> My weak vote would be `number` for the transaction type since we know it fits within 52 bits.

author: sky.cactus
content: Soo... the spec for 2930 needs to be updated.  ðŸ˜–

author: sky.cactus
content:
From 2718 (for very good reason):
> All signatures for future transaction types **SHOULD** include the TransactionType as the first byte of the signed data. This makes it so we do not have to worry about signatures for one transaction type being used as signaturese for a different transaction type.
> 
> While it is strongly recommended that all future transactions sign the first byte to ensure that there is no problem with signature reuse, the authors acknowledge that this may not always make sense or be possible. One example where this isnâ€™t possible is wrapped legacy transactions that are signature compatible with the legacy signing scheme. Another potential situation is one where transactions donâ€™t have a signature in the traditional sense and instead have some other mechanism for determining validity.

author: sky.cactus
content:
Then over in 2930:
> The `yParity, senderR, senderS` elements of this transaction represent a secp256k1 signature over `keccak256(rlp([1, chainId, nonce, gasPrice, gasLimit, to, value, data, access_list]))`.

author: sky.cactus
content: The transaction type is *not* the first byte of the signed data, which can lead to signature collisions between transaction types.

author: sky.cactus
content:
It should be:
```
keccak256(1 || rlp([chainId, nonce, gasPrice, gasLimit, to, value, data, access_list]))
```

author: sky.cactus
content: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/3253

author: sky.cactus
content: Thanks for catching that <@489256758989029405>!

author: draganrakita
content: Should i change this, it makes a lot of sense for it to be `keccak256(1 || ...)`.
